WeightReturn to Explanation
A measure of the heaviness of an object. The force by which a body is attracted toward the center of the Earth (or another celestial body) by gravity. Weight is equal to the mass of the body times the local value of gravitational acceleration. One of the four main forces acting on an aircraft. Equivalent to the actual weight of the aircraft. It acts downward through the aircraft’s center of gravity toward the center of the Earth. Weight opposes lift.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

A measure of the pull of gravity acting on the mass of an object.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician General Handbook (FAA-H-8083-30)

One of the four main forces acting on a helicopter. Equivalent to the actual weight of the helicopter. It acts downward toward the center of the earth.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Helicopter Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-21A)

The force exerted by an aircraft from the pull of gravity.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge (FAA-H-8083-25A)

A measure of the heaviness of an object. One of the four main forces acting on an aircraft. The force by which a body is attracted downward toward the center of the Earth (or another celestial body) by gravity. Weight is equal to the mass of the body times the local value of gravitational acceleration.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Weight

Load FactorReturn to Explanation
The ratio of the load supported by the airplane’s wings to the actual weight of the aircraft and its contents. Also referred to as G-loading.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

Load factor means the ratio of a specified load to the total weight of the aircraft. The specified load is expressed in terms of any of the following: aerodynamic forces, inertia forces, or ground or water reactions.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Federal Aviation Regulations (CFR 14 Part 1)

The ratio of the load supported by the glider’s wings to the actual weight of the aircraft and its contents.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Glider Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-13A)

The ratio of a specified load weight to the total weight of the aircraft.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Helicopter Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-21A)

The ratio of a specified load to the total weight of the aircraft. The specified load is expressed in terms of any of the following: aerodynamic forces, inertial forces, or ground or water reactions.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge (FAA-H-8083-25A)

The ration of the maximum load an aircraft can sustain to the total weight of the aircraft. Normal category aircraft must have a load factor of a least 3.8, Utility category aircraft 4.4, and acrobatic category aircraft, 6.0.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight and Balance Handbook (FAA-H-8083-1A)

The ratio of a specified load to the total weight of the aircraft. The specified load is expressed in terms of any of the following: aerodynamic forces, inertial forces, or ground or water reactions. Also referred to as G-loading.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

Center of GravityReturn to Explanation
Center of Gravity (CG): The point at which an airplane would balance if it were possible to suspend it at that point. It is the mass center of the airplane, or the theoretical point at which the entire weight of the airplane is assumed to be concentrated. It may be expressed in inches from the reference datum, or in percent of mean aerodynamic chord (MAC). The location depends on the distribution of weight in the airplane.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

The location on an aircraft about which the force of gravity is concentrated.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Airframe Handbook (FAA-H-8083-31)

The point about which the nose-heavy and tail-heavy moments are exactly equal in magnitude.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician General Handbook (FAA-H-8083-30)

The theoretical point where the entire weight of the helicopter is considered to be concentrated.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Helicopter Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-21A)

(GAMA) The point at which an airplane would balance if suspended. Its distance from the reference datum is determined by dividing the total moment by the total weight of the airplane. It is the mass center of the aircraft, or the theoretical point at which the entire weight of the aircraft is assumed to be concentrated. It may be expressed in percent of MAC (mean aerodynamic cord) or in inches from the reference datum.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight and Balance Handbook (FAA-H-8083-1A)

Center of gravity (CG): The point at which an aircraft would balance if it were possible to suspend it at that point. It is the mass center of the aircraft, or the theoretical point at which the entire weight of the WSC is assumed to be concentrated. It may be expressed in inches from the reference datum, or in percent of mean aerodynamic chord (MAC). The location depends on the distribution of weight in the aircraft.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Center of Gravity

We thank you for your understanding and use of good judgment in such cases.

Airplane means an engine-driven fixed-wing aircraft heavier than air, that is supported in flight by the dynamic reaction of the air against its wings.

source: FAA Federal Aviation Regulations (CFR 14 Part 1)

HorizonReturn to Explanation
The line of sight boundary between the earth and the sky.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

The apparent or visible junction of the earth and sky as seen from any specific position. Also called the apparent, visible, or local horizon. A horizontal plane passing through a point of vision or perspective center. The apparent or visible horizon approximates the true horizon only when the point of vision is very close to sea level.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Flight Navigator's Handbook (FAA-H-8083-18)

The distant line along which the earth and sky appear to meet. Obstructions are not considered as part of the horizon.
Report an issue with this definition

source: NOAA National Weather Service Glossary

Longitudinal AxisReturn to Explanation
An imaginary line through an aircraft from nose to tail, passing through its center of gravity. The longitudinal axis is also called the roll axis of the aircraft. Movement of the ailerons rotates an airplane about its longitudinal axis.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

An imaginary line, passing through the center of gravity of an airplane, and extending lengthwise through it from nose to tail.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Airframe Handbook (FAA-H-8083-31)

A straight line through the center of gravity of an aircraft parallel to the fuselage.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Flight Navigator's Handbook (FAA-H-8083-18)

An imaginary straight line running through the fuselage from nose to tail. Roll movement occurs around the longitudinal axis, and is controlled by the ailerons.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Glider Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-13A)

An imaginary line through an aircraft from nose to tail, passing through its center of gravity.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight and Balance Handbook (FAA-H-8083-1A)

An imaginary line through an aircraft from nose to tail, passing through its center of gravity about which the aircraft rolls in flight. The longitudinal axis is also called the roll axis of the aircraft.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Longitudinal Axis

Question Classification

  • FAA Learning Statement Code: PLT168 - Recall angle of attack - characteristics / forces / principles
  • checkride.com Question ID: 11175

References

  • PIlots Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge
  • FAA Learning Statement Code: PLT168 - Recall angle of attack - characteristics / forces / principles
  • Study Area: Aerodynamics
Question ID: PVT779
(www.checkride.com #1966)
What is the antidote when a pilot has the hazardous attitude of "Invulnerability"?

A.It will not happen to me.
B.It could happen to me.
C.It can not be that bad.

Answer B is correct.

This question is a fairly easy one if you don't skip or misunderstand the meaning of the word "antidote."

An antidote is something that you take to counter a poison--in this case, the poisonous attitude of 'invulnerability.' Both of the incorrect answers in this case are examples of lines of thought or action where the thinker incorrectly/unjustifiably dismisses/minimizes possible negative consequences.

Some of you reading this may initially find such questions to be pedantic and "beneath you" in the sense that this stuff seems fairly obvious. While the content may indeed at some level be obvious, training yourself to act upon such "obvious" information is a whole different story. Try to consciously consider the "antidote" attitude when you find yourself getting into a hazardous attitude trap.



Terms and Definitions
  • Antidote
  • Hazardous Attitudes
  • Attitude
  • Negative
  • Contents
  • Training
  • Request a Term
AntidoteReturn to Explanation
  1. A remedy to counteract the effects of poison (often followed by "against," "for," or "to").
  2. Something that counteracts or prevents something harmful.
Report an issue with this definition

source: Wikitionary / Wikipedia and Related Sources (Edited)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Antidote

In order to aid effective learning, quick look-up definitions such the above are automatically linked to from certain text presented by our app. While having such definitions can be very helpful, sometimes definitions shown might not be contextually correct. We thank you for your understanding and use of good judgment in such cases.

AttitudeReturn to Explanation
Attitude is a personal motivational predisposition to respond to persons, situations, or events in a given manner that can, nevertheless, be changed or modified through training. A short of mental shortcut to decision making.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aeronautical Decision Making (AC 60-22)

The position of an aircraft as determined by the relationship of its axes and a reference, usually the earth’s horizon.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

The position of an aircraft as determined by the relationship of its axes and a reference, usually the earth's horizon.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

  1. The position of the body or way of carrying oneself; posture.
  2. Disposition or state of mind.
  3. (aeronautics, nautical, engineering) The orientation of a vehicle or other object relative to the horizon, direction of motion, other objects, etc.
Report an issue with this definition

source: Wikitionary / Wikipedia and Related Sources (Edited)

TrainingReturn to Explanation
Repeated areas of rain, typically associated with thunderstorms, that move over the same region in a relatively short period of time and are capable of producing excessive rainfall totals. Train(ing) echoes can frequently be a source of flash flooding.

source: NOAA National Weather Service Glossary

Question Classification

  • FAA Question Code: PVT779
  • FAA Learning Statement Code: PLT103 - Recall Aeronautical Decision Making (ADM) - hazardous attitudes
  • checkride.com Question ID: 1966

References

  • FAA Learning Statement Code: PLT103 - Recall Aeronautical Decision Making (ADM) - hazardous attitudes
  • Study Area: Physiology and Psychology
Question ID: PVT152
(www.checkride.com #5413)
In what flight condition is torque effect the greatest in a single-engine airplane?

A.High airspeed, high power, high angle of attack.
B.Low airspeed, high power, high angle of attack.
C.Low airspeed, low power, low angle of attack.

Answer B is correct.

AC 61-23, chapter 1 states:

The effect of torque increases in direct proportion to engine power, airspeed, and airplane attitude. If the power setting is high, the airspeed slow, and the angle of attack high, the effect of torque is greater. During takeoffs and climbs, when the effect of torque is most pronounced, the pilot must apply sufficient right rudder pressure to counteract the left-turning tendency and maintain a straight takeoff path.

Torque reaction involves Newton's Third Law of Motion: for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. As applied to the aircraft, this means that as the internal engine parts and propeller are revolving in one direction, an equal force is trying to rotate the aircraft in the opposite direction

When the aircraft is airborne, this force is acting around the longitudinal axis, tending to make the aircraft roll. To compensate for roll tendency, some of the older aircraft are rigged in a manner to create more lift on the wing that is being forced downward. The more modern aircraft are designed with the engine offset to counteract this effect of torque.

NOTE: Most United States built aircraft engines rotate the propeller clockwise, as viewed from the pilot's seat. The discussion here is with reference to those engines.

Generally, the compensating factors are permanently set so that they compensate for this force at cruising speed, since most of the aircraft's operating lift is at that speed. However, aileron trim tabs permit further adjustment for other speeds.

When the aircraft's wheels are on the ground during the takeoff roll, an additional turning moment around the vertical axis is induced by torque reaction. As the left side of the aircraft is being forced down by torque reaction, more weight is being placed on the left main landing gear. This results in more ground friction, or drag, on the left tire than on the right, causing a further turning moment to the left. The magnitude of this moment is dependent on many variables. Some of these variables are:

  • Size and horsepower of engine,
  • Size of propeller and the rpm,
  • Size of the aircraft, and
  • Condition of the ground surface.
This yawing moment on the takeoff roll is corrected by the pilot's proper use of the rudder or rudder trim.

  • Request a Term
TorqueReturn to Explanation
A twisting, gyroscopic force acting in opposition to an axis of rotation, such as with a turning propeller; aka Torsion.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aerosense Glossary

  1. A resistance to turning or twisting.
  2. Forces that produce a twisting or rotating motion.
  3. In an airplane, the tendency of the aircraft to turn (roll) in the opposite direction of rotation of the engine and propeller.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

A force that produces or tries to produce rotation.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Airframe Handbook (FAA-H-8083-31)

The tendency of a force to cause or change rotational motion of a body.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician General Handbook (FAA-H-8083-30)

A force that produces or tries to produce rotation.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Powerplant Handbook (FAA-H-8083-32)

In helicopters with a single, main rotor system, the tendency of the helicopter to turn in the opposite direction of the main rotor rotation.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Helicopter Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-21A)

  1. A resistance to turning or twisting.
  2. Forces that produce a twisting or rotating motion.
  3. In a WSC, the tendency of the aircraft to turn (roll) in the opposite direction of rotation of the engine and propeller.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

Torque, moment, or moment of force (see the terminology below) is the tendency of a force to rotate an object about an axis, fulcrum, or pivot. Just as a force is a push or a pull, a torque can be thought of as a twist to an object. Mathematically, torque is defined as the cross product of the lever-arm distance vector and the force vector, which tends to produce rotation.

Loosely speaking, torque is a measure of the turning force on an object such as a bolt or a flywheel. For example, pushing or pulling the handle of a wrench connected to a nut or bolt produces a torque (turning force) that loosens or tightens the nut or bolt.

The symbol for torque is typically the Greek letter tau. When it is called moment of force, it is commonly denoted M.

The magnitude of torque depends on three quantities: the force applied, the length of the lever arm connecting the axis to the point of force application, and the angle between the force vector and the lever arm.

Report an issue with this definition

source: Wikitionary / Wikipedia and Related Sources (Edited)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Torque

In order to aid effective learning, quick look-up definitions such the above are automatically linked to from certain text presented by our app. While having such definitions can be very helpful, sometimes definitions shown might not be contextually correct. We thank you for your understanding and use of good judgment in such cases.

AirplaneReturn to Explanation
Airplane means an engine-driven fixed-wing aircraft heavier than air, that is supported in flight by the dynamic reaction of the air against its wings.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Federal Aviation Regulations (CFR 14 Part 1)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Airplane

We thank you for your understanding and use of good judgment in such cases.

AirspeedReturn to Explanation
The speed of an aircraft relative to its surrounding air mass.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Flight Navigator's Handbook (FAA-H-8083-18)

(Refer to 14 CFR Part 1.) The speed of an aircraft relative to its surrounding air mass. The unqualified term "airspeed" means one of the following:
  1. Indicated Airspeed- The speed shown on the aircraft airspeed indicator. This is the speed used in pilot/controller communications under the general term "airspeed. (Refer to 14 CFR Part 1.)
  2. True Airspeed- The airspeed of an aircraft relative to undisturbed air. Used primarily in flight planning and en route portion of flight. When used in pilot/controller communications, it is referred to as "true airspeed and not shortened to "airspeed."
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Pilot/Controller Glossary

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Airspeed

In order to aid effective learning, quick look-up definitions such the above are automatically linked to from certain text presented by our app. While having such definitions can be very helpful, sometimes definitions shown might not be contextually correct. We thank you for your understanding and use of good judgment in such cases.

PowerReturn to Explanation
Implies work rate or units of work per unit of time, and as such, it is a function of the speed at which the force is developed. The term “power required” is generally associated with reciprocating engines.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

The time rate of doing work. Power is force multiplied by distance (work), divided by time.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Airframe Handbook (FAA-H-8083-31)

Power is the time rate at which work is done or energy is transferred.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician General Handbook (FAA-H-8083-30)

The time rate of doing work. Power is found by dividing the amount of work done, measured in foot-pounds, by the time in seconds or minutes used to do the work. Power may be expressed in foot-pounds of work per minute or in horsepower. One horsepower is 33,000 foot-pounds of work done in one minute, or 550 foot pounds of work done in one second.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Powerplant Handbook (FAA-H-8083-32)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Power

In order to aid effective learning, quick look-up definitions such the above are automatically linked to from certain text presented by our app. While having such definitions can be very helpful, sometimes definitions shown might not be contextually correct. We thank you for your understanding and use of good judgment in such cases.

Angle of AttackReturn to Explanation
The acute angle at which a moving airfoil meets the airstream.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aerosense Glossary

Angle of Attack (AoA): The acute angle between the chord line of the airfoil and the direction of the relative wind.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

The acute angle formed between the chord line of an airfoil and the direction of the air that strikes the airfoil.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Airframe Handbook (FAA-H-8083-31)

The acute angle between the chord line of a propeller blade and the relative wind. The angle of attack is affected by both the engine rpm and the forward speed of the aircraft.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Powerplant Handbook (FAA-H-8083-32)

The angle formed between the relative wind and the chord line of the wing.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Glider Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-13A)

The angle between the airfoil’s chord line and the relative wind.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Helicopter Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-21A)

The acute angle formed between the chord line of an airfoil and the direction of the air striking the airfoil.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge (FAA-H-8083-25A)

Angle of attack (AOA): The acute angle between the chord line of the airfoil and the direction of the relative wind.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

AC 61-23Return to Explanation
The Pilot’s Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge (PHAK) is an FAA publication that provides basic knowledge that is essential for pilots. This handbook introduces pilots to the broad spectrum of knowledge that will be needed as they progress in their pilot training. Except for the Code of Federal Regulations pertinent to civil aviation, most of the knowledge areas applicable to pilot certification are presented. This handbook is useful to beginning pilots, as well as those pursuing more advanced pilot certificates.
Report an issue with this definition

source: Wikitionary / Wikipedia and Related Sources (Edited)

DirectReturn to Explanation
Straight line flight between two navigational aids, fixes, points, or any combination thereof. When used by pilots in describing off-airway routes, points defining direct route segments become compulsory reporting points unless the aircraft is under radar contact.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Pilot/Controller Glossary

ProportionReturn to Explanation
A proportion is a statement of equality between two or more ratios. The example of A is to B as C is to D can be represented A:B = C:D or A/B = C/D.

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician General Handbook (FAA-H-8083-30)

AttitudeReturn to Explanation
Attitude is a personal motivational predisposition to respond to persons, situations, or events in a given manner that can, nevertheless, be changed or modified through training. A short of mental shortcut to decision making.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aeronautical Decision Making (AC 60-22)

The position of an aircraft as determined by the relationship of its axes and a reference, usually the earth’s horizon.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

The position of an aircraft as determined by the relationship of its axes and a reference, usually the earth's horizon.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

  1. The position of the body or way of carrying oneself; posture.
  2. Disposition or state of mind.
  3. (aeronautics, nautical, engineering) The orientation of a vehicle or other object relative to the horizon, direction of motion, other objects, etc.
Report an issue with this definition

source: Wikitionary / Wikipedia and Related Sources (Edited)

TakeoffsReturn to Explanation
Takeoff is the phase of flight in which an aerospace vehicle goes from the ground to flying in the air.

For aircraft that take off horizontally, this usually involves starting with a transition from moving along the ground (taxiing) on a runway. For balloons, helicopters and some specialized fixed-wing aircraft (VTOL aircraft such as the Harrier), no runway is needed. Takeoff is the opposite of landing.

Report an issue with this definition

source: Wikitionary / Wikipedia and Related Sources (Edited)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Takeoffs

In order to aid effective learning, quick look-up definitions such the above are automatically linked to from certain text presented by our app. While having such definitions can be very helpful, sometimes definitions shown might not be contextually correct. We thank you for your understanding and use of good judgment in such cases.

RudderReturn to Explanation
The movable part of a vertical airfoil which controls the YAW of an aircraft; the fixed part being the FIN.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aerosense Glossary

The movable primary control surface mounted on the trailing edge of the vertical fin of an airplane. Movement of the rudder rotates the airplane about its vertical axis.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

PressureReturn to Explanation
Force per unit area. Hydraulic and pneumatic pressure are normally given in units of pounds per square inch (psi).
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Airframe Handbook (FAA-H-8083-31)

The amount of force acting on a specific amount of surface area, typically measured in pounds per square inch or psi.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician General Handbook (FAA-H-8083-30)

A measure of force applied uniformly over a given unit of surface area.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Powerplant Handbook (FAA-H-8083-32)

The exertion of force upon a surface by a fluid (e.g., the atmosphere) in contact with it.
Report an issue with this definition

source: NOAA National Weather Service Glossary

MaintainReturn to Explanation
  1. Concerning altitude/flight level, the term means to remain at the altitude/flight level specified. The phrase "climb and" or "descend and" normally precedes "maintain" and the altitude assignment; e.g., "descend and maintain 5,000."
  2. Concerning other ATC instructions, the term is used in its literal sense; e.g., maintain VFR.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Pilot/Controller Glossary

Takeoff is the phase of flight in which an aerospace vehicle goes from the ground to flying in the air.

For aircraft that take off horizontally, this usually involves starting with a transition from moving along the ground (taxiing) on a runway. For balloons, helicopters and some specialized fixed-wing aircraft (VTOL aircraft such as the Harrier), no runway is needed. Takeoff is the opposite of landing.

Newton's Third Law of MotionReturn to Explanation
Whenever one body exerts a force on another, the second body always exerts on the first, a force that is equal in magnitude but opposite in direction.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

When one body exerts a force on a second body, the second body simultaneously exerts a force equal in magnitude and opposite in direction on the first body.
Report an issue with this definition

source: Wikitionary / Wikipedia and Related Sources (Edited)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Newton's Third Law of Motion

AircraftReturn to Explanation
A device that is used or intended to be used for flight in the air.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Balloon Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-11)

Aircraft means a device that is used or intended to be used for flight in the air.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Federal Aviation Regulations (CFR 14 Part 1)

Device(s) that are used or intended to be used for flight in the air, and when used in air traffic control terminology, may include the flight crew.

Any machine that can derive support in the atmosphere from the reactions of the air other than the reactions of the air against the earth's surface.

Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Pilot/Controller Glossary

A device that is used, or intended to be used, for flight.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Risk Management Handbook (FAA-H-8083-2)

A device that is used or intended to be used for flight in the air.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

A vehicle capable of atmospheric flight due to interaction with the air, such as buoyancy or lift.

Note: the plural of "aircraft" is "aircraft", not "aircrafts."

  • Correct: "One aircraft, Three aircraft"
  • Incorrect: "One aircraft, Three aircrafts."
Report an issue with this definition

source: Wikitionary / Wikipedia and Related Sources (Edited)

Longitudinal AxisReturn to Explanation
An imaginary line through an aircraft from nose to tail, passing through its center of gravity. The longitudinal axis is also called the roll axis of the aircraft. Movement of the ailerons rotates an airplane about its longitudinal axis.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

An imaginary line, passing through the center of gravity of an airplane, and extending lengthwise through it from nose to tail.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Airframe Handbook (FAA-H-8083-31)

A straight line through the center of gravity of an aircraft parallel to the fuselage.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Flight Navigator's Handbook (FAA-H-8083-18)

An imaginary straight line running through the fuselage from nose to tail. Roll movement occurs around the longitudinal axis, and is controlled by the ailerons.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Glider Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-13A)

An imaginary line through an aircraft from nose to tail, passing through its center of gravity.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight and Balance Handbook (FAA-H-8083-1A)

An imaginary line through an aircraft from nose to tail, passing through its center of gravity about which the aircraft rolls in flight. The longitudinal axis is also called the roll axis of the aircraft.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

RollReturn to Explanation
Of the three axes in flight, this specifies the action around a central point. Compare PITCH and YAW.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aerosense Glossary

The motion of the aircraft about the longitudinal axis. It is controlled by the ailerons.

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

Rotation of an aircraft about its longitudinal axis.

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Airframe Handbook (FAA-H-8083-31)

LiftReturn to Explanation
The force exerted on the top of a moving airfoil as a low-pressure area [vacuum] that causes a wingform to rise. AIRFOILs do not "float" on air, as is often assumed—like a boat hull floats on water—but are "pulled up" [lifted] by low air pressures trying to equalize.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aerosense Glossary

One of the four main forces acting on an aircraft. On a fixed-wing aircraft, an upward force created by the effect of airflow as it passes over and under the wing.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

One of the four main forces acting on a helicopter. It acts perpendicular to the relative wind.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Helicopter Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-21A)

Lift is a component of the total aerodynamic force on an airfoil and acts perpendicular to the relative wind.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge (FAA-H-8083-25A)

One of the four main forces acting on an aircraft. On a WSC, an upward force created by the effect of airflow as it passes over and under the wing.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Lift

In order to aid effective learning, quick look-up definitions such the above are automatically linked to from certain text presented by our app. While having such definitions can be very helpful, sometimes definitions shown might not be contextually correct. We thank you for your understanding and use of good judgment in such cases.

Airfoil attached to each side of the fuselage and are the main lifting surfaces that support the airplane in flight.

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

ReferenceReturn to Explanation
As a noun:
  1. A relationship or relation (to something). ?
  2. A measurement one can compare to.
  3. Information about a person, provided by someone (a referee) with whom they are well acquainted
  4. A reference work.
  5. (semantics) A relation between objects in which one object designates, or acts as a means by which to connect to or link to, another object.
As a verb:
  1. to refer to, to make reference to, to cite
  2. to mention
Report an issue with this definition

source: Wikitionary / Wikipedia and Related Sources (Edited)

Explanation > Reference

We thank you for your understanding and use of good judgment in such cases.

SpeedReturn to Explanation
The distance traveled in a given time.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

The speed of an aircraft relative to its surrounding air mass. The unqualified term "airspeed" means one of the following:
  1. Indicated Airspeed- The speed shown on the aircraft airspeed indicator. This is the speed used in pilot/controller communications under the general term "airspeed. (Refer to 14 CFR Part 1.)
  2. True Airspeed- The airspeed of an aircraft relative to undisturbed air. Used primarily in flight planning and en route portion of flight. When used in pilot/controller communications, it is referred to as "true airspeed and not shortened to "airspeed." (See AIRSPEED) (See GROUND SPEED)
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Pilot/Controller Glossary

The distance traveled in a given time.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Speed

In order to aid effective learning, quick look-up definitions such the above are automatically linked to from certain text presented by our app. While having such definitions can be very helpful, sometimes definitions shown might not be contextually correct. We thank you for your understanding and use of good judgment in such cases.

AileronReturn to Explanation
The movable areas of a wingform that control or affect the roll of an aircraft by working opposite one another—up-aileron on the right wing and down-aileron on the left wing. French: aileron small wing, diminutive of aile, from Latin: ala, wing. The word "aisle" also derives from the same root. (Above pic proves that birds invented ailerons long before man did.)
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aerosense Glossary

Ailerons are primary flight control surfaces mounted on the trailing edges airplane wings, near the tip. Ailerons control roll about the longitudinal axis.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Aileron

We thank you for your understanding and use of good judgment in such cases.

Trim TabReturn to Explanation
A small, auxiliary control surface in the trailing edge of a wingform, adjustable mechanically or by hand, to counteract ("trim") aerodynamic forces on the main control surfaces.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aerosense Glossary

A small auxiliary hinged portion of a movable control surface that can be adjusted during flight to a position resulting in a balance of control forces.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

A small control tab mounted on the trailing edge of a movable control surface. The tab may be adjusted to provide an aerodynamic force to hold the surface on which it is mounted deflected in order to trim the airplane for hands-off flight at a specified airspeed.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Airframe Handbook (FAA-H-8083-31)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Trim Tab

GroundReturn to Explanation
The voltage reference point in an aircraft electrical system. Ground has zero electrical potential. Voltage values, both positive and negative, are measured from ground. In the United Kingdom, ground is spoken of as “earth.”
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Airframe Handbook (FAA-H-8083-31)

Takeoff RollReturn to Explanation
The total distance required for an aircraft to become airborne.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

The process whereby an aircraft is aligned with the runway centerline and the aircraft is moving with the intent to take off. For helicopters, this pertains to the act of becoming airborne after departing a takeoff area.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Pilot/Controller Glossary

MomentReturn to Explanation
The product of the weight of an item multiplied by its arm. Moments are expressed in pound-inches (lb-in). Total moment is the weight of the airplane multiplied by the distance between the datum and the CG.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

A force that causes or tries to cause an object to rotate. The value of a moment is the product of the weight of an object (or the force), multiplied by the distance between the center of gravity of the object (or the point of application of the force) and the fulcrum about which the object rotates.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Airframe Handbook (FAA-H-8083-31)

In determining weight and balance, the moment is the product of a weight multiplied by its arm.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician General Handbook (FAA-H-8083-30)

A force that causes or tries to cause an object to rotate. It is indicated by the product of the weight of an item multiplied by its arm.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight and Balance Handbook (FAA-H-8083-1A)

(GAMA) The product of the weight of an item multiplied by its arm. (Moment divided by a constant is used to simplify balance calculations by reducing the number of digits; see reduction factor.)
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight and Balance Handbook (FAA-H-8083-1A)

A force that causes or tries to cause an object to rotate. The product of the weight of an item multiplied by its arm. Moments are expressed in weight-distance measures such as pound-inches (lb-in).
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Moment

Vertical AxisReturn to Explanation
An imaginary line passing vertically through the center of gravity of an aircraft. The vertical axis is called the z-axis or the yaw axis.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

An imaginary line, passing vertically through the center of gravity of an airplane.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Airframe Handbook (FAA-H-8083-31)

An imaginary straight line drawn through the center of gravity and perpendicular to the lateral and longitudinal axes. Yaw movement occurs around the vertical axis and is controlled by the rudder.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Glider Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-13A)

An imaginary line passing vertically through the center of gravity of an aircraft. The vertical axis is called the z-axis or the yaw axis.

WeightReturn to Explanation
A measure of the heaviness of an object. The force by which a body is attracted toward the center of the Earth (or another celestial body) by gravity. Weight is equal to the mass of the body times the local value of gravitational acceleration. One of the four main forces acting on an aircraft. Equivalent to the actual weight of the aircraft. It acts downward through the aircraft’s center of gravity toward the center of the Earth. Weight opposes lift.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

A measure of the pull of gravity acting on the mass of an object.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician General Handbook (FAA-H-8083-30)

One of the four main forces acting on a helicopter. Equivalent to the actual weight of the helicopter. It acts downward toward the center of the earth.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Helicopter Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-21A)

The force exerted by an aircraft from the pull of gravity.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge (FAA-H-8083-25A)

A measure of the heaviness of an object. One of the four main forces acting on an aircraft. The force by which a body is attracted downward toward the center of the Earth (or another celestial body) by gravity. Weight is equal to the mass of the body times the local value of gravitational acceleration.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

FrictionReturn to Explanation
The opposition to movement between objects.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician General Handbook (FAA-H-8083-30)

The mechanical resistive force of one object on another object's relative movement when in contact with the first object. In meteorology, friction affects the motion of air (wind) at and near the Earth's surface.
Report an issue with this definition

source: NOAA National Weather Service Glossary

DragReturn to Explanation
The resisting force exerted on an aircraft in its line of flight opposite in direction to its motion. Compare THRUST.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aerosense Glossary

An aerodynamic force on a body acting parallel and opposite to the relative wind. The resistance of the atmosphere to the relative motion of an aircraft. Drag opposes thrust and limits the speed of the airplane.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

Fore-and-aft movement of the tip of a helicopter rotor blade in its plane of rotation.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Airframe Handbook (FAA-H-8083-31)

The force that resists the movement of the glider through the air.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Glider Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-13A)

An aerodynamic force on a body acting parallel and opposite to relative wind.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Helicopter Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-21A)

The net aerodynamic force parallel to the relative wind, usually the sum of two components: induced drag and parasite drag.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge (FAA-H-8083-25A)

An aerodynamic force on a body acting parallel and opposite to the relative wind. The resistance of the atmosphere to the relative motion of an aircraft. Drag opposes thrust and limits the speed of the aircraft.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

HorsepowerReturn to Explanation
The motive energy required to raise 550# one foot in one second, friction disregarded.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aerosense Glossary

The term, originated by inventor James Watt, means the amount of work a horse could do in one second. One horsepower equals 550 foot-pounds per second, or 33,000 foot-pounds per minute.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

A unit of mechanical power that is equal to 33,000 foot-pounds of work done in 1 minute, or 550 footpounds of work done in 1 second.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Airframe Handbook (FAA-H-8083-31)

A measure of power equal to 550 foot-pounds per second or 33,000 foot-pounds per minute and 746 Watts.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician General Handbook (FAA-H-8083-30)

The most commonly used unit of mechanical power. One horsepower is equal to 33,000 foot-pounds of work done in one second.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Powerplant Handbook (FAA-H-8083-32)

The term, originated by inventor James Watt, means the amount of work a horse could do in one second. One horsepower equals 550 foot-pounds per second, or 33,000 foot-pounds per minute.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

Question ID: PVT158
(www.checkride.com #5423)
What is the purpose of the rudder on an airplane?

A.To control roll.
B.To control overbanking tendency.
C.To control yaw.

Answer C is correct.

  • The rudder of an airplane controls yaw, that is, the airplane's movement along its vertical (yaw) axis.
  • The rudder does not control roll. This is primarily the function of the ailerons.
  • The rudder does not control overbanking tendency. Overbanking tendency is a phenomenon that is controlled through careful piloting using whatever flight controls are appropriate for the given situation.

Try not to over think this question. Recall that the vertical axis of the airplane can properly and elegantly also be referred to as the yaw axis.



Terms and Definitions
  • Rudder
  • Airplane
  • Yaw
  • Roll
  • Ailerons
  • Vertical Axis
  • Request a Term
RudderReturn to Explanation
The movable part of a vertical airfoil which controls the YAW of an aircraft; the fixed part being the FIN.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aerosense Glossary

The movable primary control surface mounted on the trailing edge of the vertical fin of an airplane. Movement of the rudder rotates the airplane about its vertical axis.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

AirplaneReturn to Explanation
Airplane means an engine-driven fixed-wing aircraft heavier than air, that is supported in flight by the dynamic reaction of the air against its wings.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Federal Aviation Regulations (CFR 14 Part 1)

Of the three axes in flight, this specifies the side-to-side movement of an aircraft on its vertical axis, as in skewing. Compare PITCH and ROLL.

source: FAA Aerosense Glossary

Rotation about the vertical axis of an aircraft.

RollReturn to Explanation
Of the three axes in flight, this specifies the action around a central point. Compare PITCH and YAW.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aerosense Glossary

The motion of the aircraft about the longitudinal axis. It is controlled by the ailerons.

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

Rotation of an aircraft about its longitudinal axis.

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Airframe Handbook (FAA-H-8083-31)

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

Question ID: PVT8V11
(www.checkride.com #8570)
Which V-speed represents maximum landing gear extended speed?

A.VLE.
B.VFE.
C.VLO.

Answer A is correct.

  • VLE represents the maximum landing gear extended speed.
  • VFE represents the maximum flap extended speed, indicated on the airspeed indicator by the top of the white arc.
  • VLO represents the maximum landing gear operation speed--this may be less than VLE.



Terms and Definitions
  • V-speed
  • Maximum Landing Gear Extended Speed
  • VLE
  • VFE
  • Maximum Flap Extended Speed
  • Airspeed Indicator
  • Arc
  • VLO
  • Maximum Landing Gear Operation Speed
  • Request a Term
V-speedReturn to Explanation
V Speeds: Designated speeds for specific flight conditions.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

In aviation, V-speeds are standard terms used to define airspeeds important or useful to the operation of all aircraft. These speeds are derived from data obtained by aircraft designers and manufacturers during flight testing and verified in most countries by government flight inspectors during aircraft type-certification testing. Using them is considered a best practice to maximize aviation safety, aircraft performance or both.

The actual speeds represented by these designators are specific to a particular model of aircraft, and are expressed in terms of the aircraft's indicated airspeed, so that pilots may use them directly, without having to apply correction factors. "V" stands for velocity.

In general aviation aircraft, the most commonly used and most safety-critical airspeeds are displayed as color-coded arcs and lines located on the face of an aircraft's airspeed indicator. The lower ends of the green arc and the white arc are the stalling speed with wing flaps retracted, and stalling speed with wing flaps fully extended, respectively. These are the stalling speeds for the aircraft at its maximum weight. The yellow range is the range in which the aircraft may be operated in smooth air, and then only with caution to avoid abrupt control movement, and the red line is the Vne, the never exceed speed.

Proper display of V speeds is an airworthiness requirement for type-certificated aircraft in most countries

Report an issue with this definition

source: Wikitionary / Wikipedia and Related Sources (Edited)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > V-speed

In order to aid effective learning, quick look-up definitions such the above are automatically linked to from certain text presented by our app. While having such definitions can be very helpful, sometimes definitions shown might not be contextually correct. We thank you for your understanding and use of good judgment in such cases.

Landing gear extended speed. The maximum speed at which an airplane can be safely flown with the landing gear extended.

Airspeed IndicatorReturn to Explanation
An instrument or device that measures the air speed of an aircraft through an air mass, but not its ground speed.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aerosense Glossary

A flight instrument that measures the pressure differential between the pitot, or ram, air pressure, and the static pressure of the air surrounding the aircraft. This differential pressure is shown in units of miles per hour, knots, or kilometers per hour.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Airframe Handbook (FAA-H-8083-31)

An instrument that displays the indicated airspeed of the aircraft derived from inputs of pitot and static pressures.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Flight Navigator's Handbook (FAA-H-8083-18)

A differential pressure gauge that measures the dynamic pressure of the air through which the aircraft is flying. Displays the craft’s airspeed, typically in knots, to the pilot.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge (FAA-H-8083-25A)

The airspeed indicator or airspeed gauge is an instrument used in an aircraft to display the craft's airspeed, typically in knots, to the pilot. In its simplest form, an ASI measures the difference in pressure between that which is generally around the craft and the increased pressure caused by propulsion. The needle tracks pressure differential but the dial is marked off as airspeed.
Report an issue with this definition

source: Wikitionary / Wikipedia and Related Sources (Edited)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Airspeed Indicator

In order to aid effective learning, quick look-up definitions such the above are automatically linked to from certain text presented by our app. While having such definitions can be very helpful, sometimes definitions shown might not be contextually correct. We thank you for your understanding and use of good judgment in such cases.

  • FAA Learning Statement Code: PLT506 - Recall V speeds - maneuvering / flap extended / gear extended
  • checkride.com Question ID: 8570

References

  • 14 CFR § S1.2 - S1.3, Part I - Definitions and Abbreviations
  • FAA Learning Statement Code: PLT506 - Recall V speeds - maneuvering / flap extended / gear extended
  • Study Area: Aerodynamics
Question ID:
(www.checkride.com #9330)
In the aeronautical decision making (ADM) process, what is the first step in neutralizing a hazardous attitude?

A.Making a rational judgement.
B.Recognizing hazardous thoughts.
C.Recognizing the invulnerability of the situation.

Answer B is correct.

Recognizing a hazardous thought is the first step in overcoming it. An important part of overcoming it is coming up with an antidote thought to the hazardous thought.

Flying safely requires the effective integration of three separate sets of skills. Most obvious are the basic stick-andrudder skills needed to control the airplane. Next, are skills related to proficient operation of aircraft systems, and last, but not least, are ADM skills.

ADM is a systematic approach to the mental process used by pilots to consistently determine the best course of action in response to a given set of circumstances. The importance of learning effective ADM skills cannot be overemphasized. While progress is continually being made in the advancement of pilot training methods, airplane equipment and systems, and services for pilots, accidents still occur. Despite all the changes in technology to improve flight safety, one factor remains the same—the human factor. While the FAA strives to eliminate errors through training and safety programs, one fact remains: humans make errors. It is estimated that approximately 80 percent of all aviation accidents are human factors related.

The ADM process addresses all aspects of decision making in the flight deck and identifies the steps involved in good decision making. While the ADM process will not eliminate errors, it will help the pilot recognize errors, and in turn enable the pilot to manage the error to minimize its effects. These steps are:

  1. Identifying personal attitudes hazardous to safe flight;
  2. Learning behavior modification techniques;
  3. Learning how to recognize and cope with stress;
  4. Developing risk assessment skills;
  5. Using all resources; and
  6. Evaluating the effectiveness of one’s ADM skills.

Historically, the term “pilot error” has been used to describe the causes of these accidents. Pilot error means that an action or decision made by the pilot was the cause, or a contributing factor that led to the accident. This definition also includes the pilot’s failure to make a decision or take action. From a broader perspective, the phrase “human factors related” more aptly describes these accidents since it is usually not a single decision that leads to an accident, but a chain of events triggered by a number of factors.

The poor judgment chain, sometimes referred to as the “error chain,” is a term used to describe this concept of contributing factors in a human factors related accident. Breaking one link in the chain normally is all that is necessary to change the outcome of the sequence of events.

Aeronautical Decision Making (ADM)Return to Explanation
Aeronautical Decision Making (ADM) is a systematic approach to the mental process used by aircraft pilots to consistently determine the best course of action in response to a given set of circumstances.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aeronautical Decision Making (AC 60-22)

StepReturn to Explanation
An abrupt break in the longitudinal lines of the float or hull, which reduces water drag and allows the pilot to vary the pitch attitude when running along the water’s surface.

source: FAA Seaplane Handbook (FAA-H-8083-23)

Hazardous AttitudesReturn to Explanation
Five aeronautical decision-making attitudes that may contribute to poor pilot judgment: anti-authority, impulsivity, invulnerability, machismo, and resignation.

Five aeronautical decision-making attitudes that may contribute to poor pilot judgment: anti-authority, impulsivity, invulnerability, macho, and resignation.

AirplaneReturn to Explanation
Airplane means an engine-driven fixed-wing aircraft heavier than air, that is supported in flight by the dynamic reaction of the air against its wings.

source: FAA Federal Aviation Regulations (CFR 14 Part 1)

AircraftReturn to Explanation
A device that is used or intended to be used for flight in the air.

source: FAA Balloon Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-11)

Aircraft means a device that is used or intended to be used for flight in the air.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Federal Aviation Regulations (CFR 14 Part 1)

Device(s) that are used or intended to be used for flight in the air, and when used in air traffic control terminology, may include the flight crew.

Any machine that can derive support in the atmosphere from the reactions of the air other than the reactions of the air against the earth's surface.

source: FAA Pilot/Controller Glossary

A device that is used, or intended to be used, for flight.

A device that is used or intended to be used for flight in the air.

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

  • Incorrect: "One aircraft, Three aircrafts."

CourseReturn to Explanation
The direction of the intended path of an aircraft over the earth.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Flight Navigator's Handbook (FAA-H-8083-18)

  1. The intended direction of flight in the horizontal plane measured in degrees from north.
  2. The ILS localizer signal pattern usually specified as the front course or the back course.
  3. The intended track along a straight, curved, or segmented MLS path. (See BEARING.) (See INSTRUMENT LANDING SYSTEM.) (See MICROWAVE LANDING SYSTEM.) (See RADIAL.)

TrainingReturn to Explanation
Repeated areas of rain, typically associated with thunderstorms, that move over the same region in a relatively short period of time and are capable of producing excessive rainfall totals. Train(ing) echoes can frequently be a source of flash flooding.

AccidentReturn to Explanation
An occurrence associated with the operation of an aircraft which takes place between the time any person boards the aircraft with the intention of flight and all such persons have disembarked, and in which any person suffers death or serious injury, or in which the aircraft receives substantial damage. (NTSB 830.2)
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Balloon Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-11)

Human FactorsReturn to Explanation
A multidisciplinary field devoted to optimizing human performance and reducing human error. It incorporates the methods and principles of the behavioral and social sciences, engineering, and physiology. It may be described as the applied science which studies people working together in concert with machines. Human factors involve variables that influence individual performance, as well as team or crew performance.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Instructor's Handbook (FAA-H-8083-9A)

The study of how people interact with their environments. In the case of general aviation, it is the study of how pilot performance is influenced by such issues as the design of cockpits, the function of the organs of the body, the effects of emotions, and the interaction and communication with the other participants of the aviation community, such as other crewmembers and air traffic control personnel.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Glider Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-13A)

The study of how people interact with their environment. In the case of general aviation, it is the study of how pilot performance is influenced by such issues as the design of cockpits, the function of the organs of the body, the effects of emotions, and the interaction and communication with other participants in the aviation community, such as other crew members and air traffic control personnel.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Helicopter Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-21A)

A multidisciplinary field encompassing the behavioral and social sciences, engineering, and physiology, to consider the variables that influence individual and crew performance for the purpose of optimizing human performance and reducing errors.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge (FAA-H-8083-25A)

A multidisciplinary field encompassing the behavioral and social sciences, engineering, and physiology, to consider the variables that influence individual and crew performance for the purpose of optimizing human performance and reducing errors.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Risk Management Handbook (FAA-H-8083-2)

FAAReturn to Explanation
The federal agency responsible to promote aviation safety through regulation and education.

source: FAA Balloon Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-11)

Federal Aviation Administration (FAA): An agency of the United States Department of Transportation with authority to regulate and oversee all aspects of civil aviation in the United States.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Risk Management Handbook (FAA-H-8083-2)

Federal Aviation Administration (FAA): The federal agency within the Department of Transportation that has the responsibility of promoting safety in the air, by both regulation and education.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

The FAA, a part of the Department of Transportation (DOT), provides a safe, secure, and efficient aerospace system that contributes to national security and the promotion of U.S. aerospace safety. As the leading authority in the international aerospace community, the FAA is responsive to the dynamic nature of user needs, economic conditions, and environmental concerns.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA/NOAA Aviation Weather Services (AC 00-45G)

Federal Aviation Administration
Report an issue with this definition

source: NOAA National Weather Service Glossary

The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is the national aviation authority of the United States. An agency of the United States Department of Transportation, it has authority to regulate and oversee all aspects of American civil aviation. The Federal Aviation Act of 1958 created the organization under the name Federal Aviation Agency. The agency adopted its current name in 1966 when it became a part of the U.S. Department of Transportation.

The FAA's roles include:

  • Regulating U.S. commercial space transportation
  • Regulating air navigation facilities' geometry and flight inspection standards
  • Encouraging and developing civil aeronautics, including new aviation technology
  • Issuing, suspending, or revoking pilot certificates
  • Regulating civil aviation to promote safety, especially through local offices called Flight Standards District Offices
  • Developing and operating a system of air traffic control and navigation for both civil and military aircraft
  • Researching and developing the National Airspace System and civil aeronautics
  • Developing and carrying out programs to control aircraft noise and other environmental effects of civil aviation
Report an issue with this definition

source: Wikitionary / Wikipedia and Related Sources (Edited)

Personal AttitudeReturn to Explanation
A personal motivational predisposition to respond to persons, situations, or events in a given manner that can, nevertheless, be changed or modified through training as a sort of mental shortcut to decision-making.

StressReturn to Explanation
The internal resistance of an object to external forces attempting to strain or deform that object. Measured in pounds per square foot or pounds per square inch (psi).
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician General Handbook (FAA-H-8083-30)

A force within an object that tries to prevent an outside force from changing its shape.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Maintenance Technician Powerplant Handbook (FAA-H-8083-32)

The body’s response to demands placed upon it.

Poor Judgment ChainReturn to Explanation
The Poor Judgment Chain is a series of mistakes that may lead to an accident or incident. Two basic principles generally associated with the creation of a poor judgment chain are:
  1. one bad decision leads to another and
  2. as a string of bad decisions grows, it reduces the number of alternatives for continued safe flight
Aeronautical Decision Making is intended to break the poor judgment chain before it can cause an accident or incident.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aeronautical Decision Making (AC 60-22)

A series of mistakes that may lead to an accident or incident. Two basic principles generally associated with the creation of a poor judgment chain are:
  1. one bad decision often leads to another; and
  2. as a string of bad decisions grows, it reduces the number of subsequent alternatives for continued safe flight.
Aeronautical decision-making is intended to break the poor judgment chain before it can cause an accident or incident.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Instructor's Handbook (FAA-H-8083-9A)

A series of mistakes that may lead to an accident or incident. Two basic principles generally associated with the creation of a poor judgment chain are: (1) one bad decision often leads to another; and (2) as a string of bad decisions grows, it reduces the number of subsequent alternatives for continued safe flight. ADM is intended to break the poor judgment chain before it can cause an accident or incident.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Risk Management Handbook (FAA-H-8083-2)

Return to Explanation

Error ChainReturn to Explanation
A series of mistakes that may lead to an accident or incident. Two basic principles generally associated with the creation of an error chain are: (1) one bad decision often leads to another; and (2) as a string of bad decisions grows, it reduces the number of subsequent alternatives for continued safe flight. Aeronautical decision making is intended to break the error chain before it can cause an accident or incident. Evaporation. The transformation of a liquid to a gaseous state, such as the change of water to water vapor.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

References

  • AC 60-22

Question Classification

  • FAA Learning Statement Code: PLT103 - Recall Aeronautical Decision Making (ADM) - hazardous attitudes
  • checkride.com Question ID: 9330

References

  • AC 60-22
  • FAA Learning Statement Code: PLT103 - Recall Aeronautical Decision Making (ADM) - hazardous attitudes
  • Study Area: Physiology and Psychology
Question ID: COM877
(www.checkride.com #562)
What are some of the hazardous attitudes dealt with in Aeronautical Decision Making (ADM)?

A.Poor decision making, situational awareness, and judgment.
B.Risk management, stress management, and risk elements.
C.Antiauthority (don't tell me), impulsivity (do something quickly without thinking), macho (I can do it).

Answer C is correct.

AC 60-22, Aeronautical Decision Making, states:

HAZARDOUS ATTITUDES.
ADM addresses the following five hazardous attitudes.
  1. Antiauthority (don't tell me!). This attitude is found in people who do not like anyone telling them what to do. In a sense they are saying no one can tell me what to do. They may be resentful of having someone tell them what to do or may regard rules, regulations, and procedures as silly or unnecessary. However, it is always your prerogative to question authority if you feel it is in error.
  2. Impulsivity (do something quickly!) is the attitude of people who frequently feel the need to do something - anything - immediately. They do not stop to think about what they are about to do, they do not select the best alternative, and they do the first thing that comes to mind.
  3. Invulnerability (it won't happen to me). Many people feel that accidents happen to others, but never to them. They know accidents can happen, and they know that anyone can be affected. They never really feel or believe that they will be personally involved. Pilots who think this way are more likely to take chances and increase risk.
  4. Macho (I can do it). Pilots who are always trying to prove that they are better than anyone else are thinking I can do it - I'll show them. Pilots with this type of attitude will try to prove themselves by taking risks in order to impress others. While this pattern is thought to be a male characteristic, women are equally susceptible.
  5. Resignation (what's the use?). Pilots who think what's the use? do not see themselves as being able to make a great deal of difference in what happens to them. When things go well, the pilot is apt to think that's good luck. When things go badly, the pilot may feel that someone is out to get me, or attribute it to bad luck. The pilot will leave the action to others, for better or worse. Sometimes, such pilots will even go along with unreasonable requests just to be a "nice guy."

MachoReturn to Explanation
Tending to display (or over-display) stereotypically "masculine" characteristics, such as domineering, fierceness, bravado, etc., in ways that are showily and histrionically tough. In English, the term is generally not used as a compliment but rather is used to criticize a subject's behavior. The origin of the term is the Spanish word "macho" which means "male," and is etymologically related to the latin word "masculus" from which we get the term "masculine."
Report an issue with this definition

source: Wikitionary / Wikipedia and Related Sources (Edited)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Macho

In order to aid effective learning, quick look-up definitions such the above are automatically linked to from certain text presented by our app. While having such definitions can be very helpful, sometimes definitions shown might not be contextually correct. We thank you for your understanding and use of good judgment in such cases.

AC 60-22Return to Explanation
Advisory Circular (AC) 60-22 provides introductory material, background information, and reference material on Aeronautical Decision Making (ADM). The material in this AC provides a systematic approach to risk assessment and stress management in aviation, illustrates how personal attitudes can influence decision making, and how those attitudes can be modified to enhance safety in the cockpit.

This AC also provides instructors with methods for teaching ADM techniques and skills in conjunction with conventional flight instruction.

Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aeronautical Decision Making (AC 60-22)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > AC 60-22

In order to aid effective learning, quick look-up definitions such the above are automatically linked to from certain text presented by our app. While having such definitions can be very helpful, sometimes definitions shown might not be contextually correct. We thank you for your understanding and use of good judgment in such cases.

Aeronautical Decision MakingReturn to Explanation
Aeronautical Decision Making (ADM) is a systematic approach to the mental process used by aircraft pilots to consistently determine the best course of action in response to a given set of circumstances.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aeronautical Decision Making (AC 60-22)

Aeronautical Decision Making (ADM): A systematic approach to the mental process used by pilots to consistently determine the best course of action in response to a given set of circumstances.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge (FAA-H-8083-25A)

A systematic approach to the mental process used consistently by pilots to determine the best course of action in response to a given set of circumstances. It is what a pilot intends to do based on the latest information he or she has.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Risk Management Handbook (FAA-H-8083-2)

Aeronautical decision-making (ADM): A systematic approach to the mental process used by pilots to consistently determine the best course of action in response to a given set of circumstances.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Aeronautical Decision Making

AttitudeReturn to Explanation
Attitude is a personal motivational predisposition to respond to persons, situations, or events in a given manner that can, nevertheless, be changed or modified through training. A short of mental shortcut to decision making.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aeronautical Decision Making (AC 60-22)

The position of an aircraft as determined by the relationship of its axes and a reference, usually the earth’s horizon.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Airplane Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-3A)

The position of an aircraft as determined by the relationship of its axes and a reference, usually the earth's horizon.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Weight Shift Control Handbook (FAA-H-8083-5)

  1. The position of the body or way of carrying oneself; posture.
  2. Disposition or state of mind.
  3. (aeronautics, nautical, engineering) The orientation of a vehicle or other object relative to the horizon, direction of motion, other objects, etc.
Report an issue with this definition

source: Wikitionary / Wikipedia and Related Sources (Edited)

AccidentReturn to Explanation
An occurrence associated with the operation of an aircraft which takes place between the time any person boards the aircraft with the intention of flight and all such persons have disembarked, and in which any person suffers death or serious injury, or in which the aircraft receives substantial damage. (NTSB 830.2)

source: FAA Balloon Flying Handbook (FAA-H-8083-11)

TypeReturn to Explanation
The term "Type":
  1. As used with respect to the certification, ratings, privileges, and limitations of airmen, means a specific make and basic model of aircraft, including modifications thereto that do not change its handling or flight characteristics. Examples include: DC-7, 1049, and F-27; and
  2. As used with respect to the certification of aircraft, means those aircraft which are similar in design. Examples include: DC-7 and DC-7C; 1049G and 1049H; and F-27 and F-27F.
  3. As used with respect to the certification of aircraft engines means those engines which are similar in design. For example, JT8D and JT8D-7 are engines of the same type, and JT9D-3A and JT9D-7 are engines of the same type.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Federal Aviation Regulations (CFR 14 Part 1)

Return to Explanation
Explanation > Type

We thank you for your understanding and use of good judgment in such cases.

PatternReturn to Explanation
The path of aircraft traffic around an airfield, at an established height and direction. At tower-controlled fields the pattern is supervised by radio (or, in non-radio or emergency conditions by red and green light signals) by air traffic controllers.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aerosense Glossary

Situational AwarenessReturn to Explanation
Situational Awareness is the accurate perception and understanding of all the factors and conditions within the four fundamental risk elements that affect safety before, during, and after the flight.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aeronautical Decision Making (AC 60-22)

The accurate perception and understanding of all the factors and conditions within the four fundamental risk elements that affect safety before, during, and after the flight.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aviation Instructor's Handbook (FAA-H-8083-9A)

Pilot knowledge of where the aircraft is in regard to location, air traffic control, weather, regulations, aircraft status, and other factors that may affect flight.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge (FAA-H-8083-25A)

JudgmentReturn to Explanation
Judgment is the mental process of recognizing and analyzing all pertinent information in a particular situation, a rational evaluation of alternative actions in response to it, and a timely decision on which action to take.
Report an issue with this definition

source: FAA Aeronautical Decision Making (AC 60-22)

The mental process of recognizing and analyzing all pertinent information in a particular situation, a rational evaluation of alternative actions in response to it, and a timely decision on which action to take.
